conclusion: The problem involves calculating the ratio of induced EMFs (ε' and ε) for a rod in a magnetic field, considering different configurations and motions.

The image shows a uniform magnetic field represented by crosses (indicating the field is directed into the plane), a straight rod moving perpendicular to the field, and a bent rod with two perpendicular segments moving along the angle bisector.
The induced EMF is proportional to the velocity of the rod and depends on the configuration and motion of the rod in the magnetic field.
The straight rod is perpendicular to the magnetic field and moves in a direction perpendicular to both the rod and the field.
The induced EMF at both ends of the straight rod is ε.
The rod is bent into two equal-length and mutually perpendicular segments and placed in a plane perpendicular to the magnetic field.
The bent rod moves at a speed v in the direction of the angle bisector of the included angle of the two segments.
The induced EMF at both ends of the bent rod is still ε.
The ratio of ε' to ε is ε/ε = 1.
